column1: '''Sigelwara Land''' is the title of an essay by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]
column2: in which is examined the etymology of ''Sigelwaran'' (and the more usual form ''Sigelhearwan'') — the [[Old English]] word for [[Wikipedia:Ethiopia|Ethiopians]].<ref name=CG>{{CG|RG}}

column1: Tolkien discusses the elements of the word ''Sigelhearwan'' and related forms
column2: as found in Old English manuscripts. ''Sigel'' can mean both "sun" and "jewel"
column3: and while the meaning of ''hearwa'' is unknown
column4: he suggests that it is connected to devils and blackness.<ref name=CG/> Tolkien writes that his tentative analysis shows that:

column3: of the background of English and northern tradition and imagination [...] ''Sigel'' may be taken as a symbol of the intricate blending of the Latin and Northern which makes the study of Old English peculiarly interesting and controversial.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien]]<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]]

column1: In early drafts of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''
column2: anglicized names for the [[Haradrim]] in the text
column4: which according to [[Christopher Tolkien]] are derived from the [[Old English]] name for the Aethiopians. [[Haradwaith]] has the anglicized name ''(Sun)Harrowland''.<ref>{{TI|Fangorn}}

column1: [[Tom Shippey]] has suggested that Tolkien's discussion of ''Sigelhearwan'' "helped to naturalise the '[[Balrogs|Balrog]]' in the traditions of the North
column2: and [...] to create (or corroborate) the image of the ''[[silmarils|silmaril]]''
column3: that fusion of 'sun' and 'jewel' in physical form".<ref>[[Tom Shippey]]
column7: the name ''[[Silmaril]]'' is rendered phonetically as ''Sigelmaerels'' containing ''sigel'' = sun

column1: The essay was originally published in two parts: part one appeared in [[Medium Ævum (Vol. 1
column4: and part two appeared in [[Medium Ævum (Vol. 3
column6: No. 2)]] in [[1934]].<ref name=CG/><ref name=TB1/> Both parts of the essay also appeared as separate offprints.<ref>[http://www.tolkienbooks.net/php/details.php?reference=13600 Sigelwara land - I. 1932]
